Dear Sheffield City Council,
I noticed that there is at least one potentially fraudulent ICNIRP safety certificate contained in Newcastle Upon Tyne City Council's planning portal, an online facility which displays details of planning applications and approvals.
A company named "Three UK Limited" - which was dissolved in the year 2015 - has somehow become the signatory for at least one bogus safety certificate (sometimes referred to as a conformity statement) for a 5G telecommunications mast installation.
Using your best and most honest endeavours, please provide:
1. A figure for the precise number of ICNIRP safety certificates related to 5G telecommunications mast installations that have been signed off by "Three UK Limited", a company that didn't exist at the time the relevant planning applications were made, and whose declared ICNIRP safety certificates are potentially fraudulent
2. Actual copies of the ICNIRP safety certificates related to 5G telecommunications mast installations that have been signed off by "Three UK Limited", a company that didn't exist at the time of the planning applications, and are therefore potentially fraudulent
3. The actual dates of the initial planning applications made for 5G telecommunications mast installations that have been allegedly ICNIRP 'safety certified' by bogus certificates, along with the named street locations and identifying nomenclature.
4. The time period stated in years, months, weeks and days, between the date of the dissolution of "Three UK Limited" (27th October 2015) and the date of the initial applications made for all of the 5G telecommunications masts concerned, having bogus safety certificates, e.g. "8 years, 2 months, 3 weeks and 5 days"
5. Given that the World Health Organisation classifies radio frequency - such as that transmitted 24/7 by 5G telecommunications masts - as a potential Type 2B carcinogen, that the power output of the affected 5G masts is unknown, that potentially a large number of safety certificates are potentially fraudulent, and that tens of thousands of Sheffield City Council Council residents have potentially been plunged into an unsafe environment, please provide detailed information explaining how Sheffield City Council Council is planning to restore council tax payers, voters, their children, and Sheffield City Council's wildlife and domestic pets back to a safe, non-hazardous environment, one which will no longer be a serious, ongoing, potential threat to residents' health and wellbeing?
Yours faithfully,
Paul Cardin

Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please accept my apologies for the "Newcastle Upon Tyne Council" typo.
Sorry!
Yours faithfully,
Paul Cardin

Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please pass this on to the person who conducts Freedom of Information reviews.
I am writing to request an internal review of Sheffield City Council's handling of my FOI request 'Bogus 5G Mast Safety Certifications'.
To state that you don't record the information requested is false. I found at least one bogus safety certificate (also referred to as a conformity statement) recorded on your online planning portal.
Please provide a copy of this one and make a search for additional bogus safety certificates, as requested, then address all of my original Points 1 thru 5
A full history of my FOI request and all correspondence is available on the Internet at this address:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/b...
Yours faithfully,
Paul Cardin

Dear Paul Cardin
Thank you for your request for an internal review relating to 5G
telecommunications mast installations, which we received on 21/07/2024. We
sincerely apologise for not meeting our legal deadline of 17/09/2024.
Thank you for your chasers of 13/11/24 and 3/02/25.
We have breached the Code of Practice under Regulation 16 of the
Environmental Information Regulations 2004, which states that we must
respond to your request for internal review within 40 working days.
We are not changing our response of 17 July 2024, and therefore not
upholding your complaint. But we are setting out the search we undertook
to meet your request, and investigating the status of an accompanying
safety certificate.
We do not specifically record 5G as a category just that a
Telecommunications Notification has been received. If you follow the link
below to the advanced search on our Planning Portal, then set the
application type to Telephone Notifications and insert the validation date
from 01/01/2015 this will bring up more than 171 applications where you
can review the documents submitted.
[1]Applications Search (sheffield.gov.uk)
Search Criteria
We have investigated whether a safety certificate should be submitted as
part of the application.
In Class A, Part 16, Schedule 2 of the General Permitted Development Order
2015 (as amended) states only that, as part of the prior approval process,
an application for telecommunications installations must be accompanied
by:
(a) a written description of the proposed development and a plan
indicating its proposed location together with any fee required to be
paid;
(b) the developer’s contact address, and the developer’s email address if
the developer is content to receive communications electronically;
(c) evidence that the requirements of sub-paragraph (1) have been
satisfied where applicable; (NB This relates to giving notice to
landowners/tenants – Sheffield City Council) and
(d) where sub-paragraph (3) the condition in paragraph A.2(5A) applies,
evidence that the Civil Aviation Authority, the Secretary of State for
Defence or the aerodrome operator operator of the civil safeguarding area
or defence safeguarding area, as the case may be, has been notified of the
proposal (NB This relates to proposals on a civil safeguarding area or a
defence safeguarding area – Sheffield City Council.)
There is no mention of the International Commission on Non-Ionizing
Radiation Protection (ICNIRP).
However, paragraph 121 of the National Planning Policy Framework states
that:
Applications for electronic communications development (including
applications for prior approval under the General Permitted Development
Order) should be supported by the necessary evidence to justify the
proposed development. This should include:
a) the outcome of consultations with organisations with an interest in the
proposed development, in particular with the relevant body where a mast is
to be installed near a school or college, or within a statutory
safeguarding zone surrounding an aerodrome, technical site or military
explosives storage area; and
b) for an addition to an existing mast or base station, a statement that
self-certifies that the cumulative exposure, when operational, will not
exceed International Commission guidelines on non-ionising radiation
protection; or
c) for a new mast or base station, evidence that the applicant has
explored the possibility of erecting antennas on an existing building,
mast or other structure and a statement that self-certifies that, when
operational, International Commission guidelines will be met. (Our
emphasis)
Applicants should therefore be submitting a certificate demonstrating
compliance with the ICNIRP guidelines.
Our response applies only to the information we hold.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be

requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[3]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
